qas.question: When was the first time humans visited Antarctica?
What was Antarctica presumed to be by the ancient thinkers?
What did Ptolemy suggest that a southern land mass would do to preserve?
Of what did early explores think Australia and South America were part?

plausible_answers.text: that South America and Australia were not part of the fabled "Antarctica",

qas.question: Who believed thet Antarctica was smaller then its actual size?
What continent has an indigenous population that arrived in the 19th century?

plausible_answers.text: a vast continent in the far south of the globe to "balance" the northern lands of Europe, Asia and North Africa

context: <b10_0>Antarctica<b10_0/> has no indigenous population and there is no evidence that it was seen by humans until the <a0_0><b5_0>19th century<b5_0/><a0_0/>. However, belief in the existence of a <b6_0>Terra Australis<b6_0/>—<b11_0>a vast continent in the far south of the globe to "<a1_0>balance<a1_0/>" the northern lands of Europe, Asia and North Africa<b11_0/>—had existed since the times of <b7_0><b12_0>Ptolemy<b12_0/><b7_0/> (1st century AD), who suggested the idea to preserve the <a2_0>symmetry<a2_0/> of all known landmasses in the world. Even in the late 17th century, after explorers had found <b8_0>that South America and Australia were not part of the fabled "<a3_0>Antarctica<a3_0/>",<b8_0/> <b9_0>geographers<b9_0/> believed that the continent was much <a4_0>larger<a4_0/> than its actual size.
